page_analysis.text_content:
Other excavation considerations

Architectural compatibility & landscape screening

• If a guard rail is required, it must be designed to be archi-
  tecturally compatible with the residence.

• Additionally, landscape screening may be required by the
  Planning Dept.

Tree protection

• A tree's root system extends well beyond the drip line and the
  roots are likely to be within the first 18" below grade.

• It is important to plan excavation in a manner that does not
  harm tree roots.

• Prior to issuance of building permit, owner to provide evidence
  that encroaching features or portions of features will not harm
  trees of any species on subject or abutting lots.

• Consult the city's Tree Technical Manual for other aspects of
  tree protection during construction.


Fig 37 Excavation, landscape screening, and guard rails

Fig 38 Excavation and tree roots

Basement

Excav
featur

When planning a basement, consider the
extent of excavation that will be required e.g.,
some excavation techniques require (for safety
reasons) that the excavation to be at a 1:1
slope which may impact tree roots severely.

41

visual_elements.description: Figure 37 is a cross-section diagram showing the side of a house with horizontal siding, a window, and a basement foundation. The ground is depicted with hatching. The caption is 'Fig 37 Excavation, landscape screening, and guard rails'.

Figure 38 is a cross-section diagram illustrating the potential conflict between building excavation and a tree's root system. It shows a house foundation labeled 'Basement' next to a large deciduous tree with an extensive underground root system. A diagonal dashed line, representing a 1:1 excavation slope, cuts through the tree's roots. The excavation area is partially labeled 'Excav featur'. An annotation explains that a 1:1 excavation slope can severely impact tree roots. The caption is 'Fig 38 Excavation and tree roots'.

additional_notes: The page has a two-column layout for the main text sections.
The page number '41' is located in the bottom right corner.
In Figure 38, a text label is partially cut off and reads 'Excav featur', likely intended to be 'Excavation feature'.
There is an annotation in a text box within Figure 38 explaining the impact of a 1:1 excavation slope on tree roots.
